As an artist whose tried both, I highly respect artists who can pull off bw. It's actually so much more difficult than colored, because there are so many abstractions and design choices you have to study up on to make it work. With color, it's much more representative of real life.

>>6482022
I'm not actually so sure color takes that much longer. If you look at most manga, there's a huge amount of hatching going on. A page could take 10 hours if a single person worked on it. I guess it depends on the art-style, though.

On top of that, bw comics are much harder to manage assistants on, because you have to create instructions and documents to get them to do what you envisioned. With coloring, you can just hire a colorist, whose sole responsibility is coloring

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Colour adds infinitely more room for fuckups for only a marginal gain, and in my opinion comics with very intricate colouring actually get tiresome to look at after a while. Black and white or simpler colour(like limited palettes or something like Blacksad or Tintin) are much better for the actual reading experience.
Sometimes colour can help salvage readability when the original art was sloppy with composition and values, like some of the worse panels in Jojo parts 5 and 6, but that's the best I can say about those coloured versions. They look putrid. In general it's less unpleasant to sit through mediocre BW, because mediocre colour like digital airbrush or garish webtoon shit lowers the art as a whole, just look at the butchered right version in picrel.
So to answer the question, I prefer BW or simple on grounds of how comfortable they are to read, since they're harder to fuck up and I prefer comics that prioritise the flow of the narrative over making good individual "illustrations"(Alex Ross is a good artist but his comics feel very awkward to me)
Colour can be good but it's a whole new dimension of complexity added on top and if rushed it's often too generic to add to the storytelling, and by necessity if it doesn't have anything of meaning to add to the whole it'll detract from it.

Limited colour is pretty good but there's something to be said for the harsh contrast of BW, maybe paired with some grey values. It's very captivating and a whole tradition in and of itself, even back from the days of oldtimey book illustrations, and I think it's one of the reasons japanese comics are so successful. It makes for very immersive reading, I suggest checking out the bit about colour and BW in McCloud's Understanding Comics. I think it ties into the whole bit at the start about cartoonier characters being closer to meaning and text than they are to literal representations, so BW leaves more room for imagination and thus emotional attachment from the reader. Colour is more flashy and eye-catching to the general public, but it's not like they're a very enduring audience and anyone familiar with comics will be receptive to BW unless they're some capeshit consoomer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6482017
Monochrome.
Color actually impedes the physical reading experience, even though it improves the observational experience. Reading is supposed to be smooth, clear, and quick. Language evolves to be smooth clear and quick. You want to communicate with as much ease as possible, and so the more visual elements you add the more bogged down that communication becomes. Your eyes become lost in the colors even if they look pretty. I feel the same way about black and white comics that use too many greys and too much detail on every page. I consider the best comics to be the ones where you not only get completely immersed in the story, but you're also turning the pages quickly so you don't get a chance to break that immersion or think about anything else. You shouldn't have to pause the story in your head to think "wow how beautiful" unless it's deliberately there for the pacing. You should only linger on a page if that is what the story calls for, like to take in the scenery or gravity. Black and white keeps your eyes moving, undistracted, turning the pages, until you hit a beautiful two page spread with intricacies deliberately rendered to make you stop and look carefully. And whatever you're looking at there, would likely be important.
As for skill level in coloring I don't care. A comic artist is a comic artist. It's a separate skill from illustration. Learning to speak in sequential imagery is a skill of its own that even the most skillful colorist could fail at. All language, including the language of sequential imagery, should be simple and concise. Highly skilled highly rendered colorful illustrations aren't simple and concise, they're just pretty. What you don't include in your art is just as important as what you do include. Manga is popular because people like it. It's just that simple. And they like it because it trims all the fat and focuses on easy visual communication and smooth eye movement, while also making its limited black and white look pretty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6449833

Some resources:
/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

Books:
Understanding Comics
Making Comics
Manga in Theory and Practice: The Craft of Creating Manga
https://mega.nz/folder/Dd4hnZTC#EjMIcTDPLbWXkAJLPHx2Kg
Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting
https://archive.org/details/RobertMcKeeStorypdf/
Even a Monkey Can Draw Manga
https://kupdf.net/download/even-a-monkey-can-draw-manga_58b9ca16e12e89233badd376_pdf
The Shonen Jump Guide to Making Manga
https://mega.nz/file/i81imLpI#GcheJ9Jjk3lw1RE9nQWgL4RG4wEBNOcRmgA-iaU6Wpg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:
> https://jasonthibault.com/definitive-list-comic-publisher-submission-guidelines/
> https://writingtipsoasis.com/best-independent-comic-book-publishers/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479670
Yeah I do that as well.
I always think that the reader will look at every panel the same way I do, when that's not even close to the truth.
The average reader will maybe spend 1-2 seconds looking at a single panel.
Obviously, really big panels or something like a 2 page spread will get more attention from the reader but for a normal panel, detail isn't needed.
Also you get a much bigger 'wow'-effect when your normal panels have little detail and look simple and then your big and important panels are full of detail and shading etc.

When I read manga/comics I sometimes spend more time looking at the speech bubbles and reading the dialogue compared to looking at the characters, let alone the backgrounds of each panel.

But I get it. You want to go all out and show what you're capable of, even in normal, boring panels.
Restraining your power level and knowing when to go all out takes practice and skill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484257
I'd say no bait and switch, especially not before you get a following. The first page can make or break a comic, and I have dropped many on the first page alone. So that idea not only risks the people who would hate your bait page but love the switch to drop it before they even see the switch, but you also risk the readers who would love the premise from the bait page and lose interest when they do see the switch.

My advice is to show the readers exactly what they're getting. The first page should set up something intriguing, a character or situation that will make people want to find out more about it and turn the page, if they do and what they get is something entirely different, they're likely to leave.

I'm in the middle of a sci-fi drama right now, and one thing I can recommend is having someone from a contrastingly primitive or out of the way environment to be your anchor to the reader. Not because they need a self insert to mindlessly ask questions like an isekai protag, but because they can be the heart of the group who lets otherwise overexposed people take a step back and focus on the world they're surrounded by, which they've become so accustomed to.

Albeit in my case, it's slightly different, since that one more down to earth character is the only human in an otherwise robot cast. But the same idea applies. And yes, it can work. I've been loving every second of this.

I don't know if it'd fit your tone, but you could make the hyperviolence have enough of an extreme bend it takes on a more dark humour aspect. It'd take a bit away from the straightforward "cool" factor.
Having the character act violently unprovoked and employ very over-the-top measures for banal issues would at least make it apparent he isn't supposed to be seen as entirely reasonable.
That kind of behaviour can be weirdly endearing, at least to me, but it doesn't exactly make the character look good. In general, even if you draw a lot of trashy B movie violence that's clearly just plain exploitation, as long as the characterisation itself doesn't paint the character as a 100% rational righteous cool dude it won't come off as glorifying it.
Hell, even when glorifying it is the intent sometimes it doesn't land. Ken is justified in executing any wasteland goons he comes across because those fuckers are cartoonishly evil, but since it's always depicted very gruesomely it takes a bit away from his "sad kind pacifist reluctantly using violence for the greater good" image and makes him seem a bit unhinged. To me it's part of the fun and charm of the comic, but it's likely unintentional.

>Typically, when creating a manga chapter, an artist draws a rough draft or "name", then a more detailed storyboard, and lastly the finalized version. However, Toriyama only draws a storyboard and then the final product simply because it is less work.[4] He did not plan the details of his stories in advance. When he began the serialization of Dragon Ball, he had only prepared storyboards for three chapters.[4] The author said that during its serialization he would wait about two days before his deadline to begin developing the storyboard. Starting around midnight, he would finish it around six in the morning and spend until that night inking, finishing everything in about a day-and-a-half.[6] Unlike other artists, he had only one assistant helping him.[23] Toriyama said that thinking only about the story for each chapter put him in some tight spots, particularly with Trunks' time travel.[4] The only thing he has confidence in is his ability to connect a story back to an earlier aspect, making it seem to have been foreshadowing.[20] The author used suggestions in fan mail he received, though generally doing the opposite of what was suggested. As an example, many fans told him not to kill Vegeta, which is exactly what he did.[24]

>>6482485
going digital is one of your problems, not that its digital, but because you have no idea how digital works.
1. use an anti-aliased brush, as in a brush that is pure pixels
2. stop using gray or black to shade. when you drew that first one did you shade with a gray marker? no? of course not, they dont exist, you shaded by having the same value, just more vibrant and deeper, not blacker.
3. stop shading entirely, shading is a beg trap and is its own study.
4. work on line-weight, notice how in your first drawing there are bits of intense thick lines and parts where its nice and soft, your new one has all the same line, and its all not working.
5. stop sketching, first draft is the final draft.
its like your raw shapes are fine, its just that nothing else is working with it, the boots and legs are nice, you just botched it all with that grey half-assed coloring and trying to emulate le nippon artists instead of trying to draw what feels good. anime is a solved medium, either fall in line or make your own feel.

Disney animator Glen Keane claims to have aphantasia. Do you think he, and other artists like him, have true aphantasia? tl;dr Do creative artists with aphantasia truly exist, or are they just full of shit/don't actually have thoughts devoid of imagery?

Hello, I hope I am not being obnoxious talking about my girlfriend again. But she has true Aphantasia (Cannot see any kind of visual memories in her mind at all).
However, she began drawing around 3 weeks ago and I am training her using a similar path to what Krenz proposes.
So far, I am seeing her progress faster than i did (I stand in stark contrast, as I am I can visualize very well).
Things I've noticed she seems naturally better at.
1.Organizing her process, from the steps on going from sketch to coloring to layer organization
2. She seems to have a better hand to eye coordination, has a lot of patience and works well.
3. Takes a lot more care in detailing, fishing, making something presentable
4. She is able to notice details in things that often go over me, as I am often lost in thought, that comes both for observation and general media consumption

I am curious to see her progress, and I'll likely post more about how effective the training is for anyone else with Aphantasia or who might simply be curious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475582
Most of us are just executing a procedure here and there trying to bend it toward "what looks good" with trial and error. Sometimes we have a strong idea and try to bend it toward that, but that makes the process harder.

I don't have aphantasia, but I don't have strong visualization abilities, and making visualizations isn't part of my or most other artists process.

I think you have some idealized notion that artists "see something in their mind" and mentally project it onto a page and trace. I'd be surprised if even one human artist on the whole planet does that.

There are artist that *do* have visualization as part of their process, like the late Kim Jung Gi, but another part of the process was building a library of processes by doing drawings from reference of lots of different things.

Draftsman, animators and painters from imagination don't have psychic powers. They just work harder than you and know more than you.

interesting topic. as someone visiting from /x/ I think I have a vague grasp on aphantasia. someone explained it like having a PC running, processing images and all kinds of visuals but then having no monitor connected to that PC. so you know what's going on, you just can't see it on the screen. that fits my situation as well. I do have a memory, I know what I look like or my mother. I just can't project it into my visual field or use my third eye to see it with my mind's eye. I have a friend of mine who can project anything into his sight, we call that hyperphantasia. btw I do have imagination since my "PC is working well". It's different for audio stuff tho. I can hear my thoughts in any voice, imagine music and instruments, sounds and stuff in my head. other senses like smell, touch and taste are less pronounced. I can feel imagined touch to some degree but taste and smell are basically not existent. I do differentiate between the third eye visualization, hypnagogia and dreams. I do dream and I see them just the same as if I'm awake. I do see flashes when tired and shortly before going to sleep. for me that's working alright. but in the waking state I just see black when closing my eyes, I just see black when thinking of a person or an object. I know the underlying concept of it though and memorized the most important details on my mental HDD.

as another anon said here, drawing for me is like starting out on a blank space, knowing what do to in theory, but going in completely blind, building up with each stroke, trial and error, not knowing where the actual drawing goes on paper.

btw some people claim they don't think in words but concepts. also some people can not read a book without moving their mouth to speak the words, because they can't think them in their head. this entire aphantasia thing is to me is so much more than just a lack of visualization. it's the understanding of the workings of our human minds in infinite complexity

I'd imagine for most people with good visualization, the memory aspect still operates just like any other memory. The famous "apple scale" could apply even for people with good visual memory - never seen a thing means nothing comes to mind, seen it a time or two and paid attention to it means you can conjure a hazy image, paid rather close attention with some comprehension and you can see a clear-ish image, see it a lot and are familiar with it and you can kinda play around with it in your head. There's other aspects, too, like somebody with decent visualization can mesh memories together while looking at things, like looking at a character, then using their memory of anatomy, come up with a visualization of the character in a certain pose in their mind. As you said, it doesn't mean it will be correct, but there is a meaningful image in their head that can be translated to the page for further refinement.

>>6483529
What do you mean by "style of perspective"? Two- and more-point perspective was avoided by almost all artists until mid-seventeenth century.

"The remarkable feature of angular perspective is that, although it was well-understood by geometers such as Pélérin (1505) and Vredemann de Vries (1605), it was avoided by virtually all artists until the middle of the seventeenth century. Aside from two paintings of doubtful attribution painted around 1440, the first successful use of full angular perspective was by Dutch artist Gerard Houckgeest in 1650. (There was limited use of the angular construction in floor tiling throughout the period, but this could easily be achieved by connecting the corners of a one-point perspective grid, and did not require an understanding of the rules of two-point construction.) Inspired to develop a radical design for his painting of the tomb of William the Silent, the king whose efforts united Holland in 1581, Houckgeest turned to Vredemann’s architectural representation technique of the oblique construction for the interior of the church at Delft. This dramatic shift from the unremitting one-point perspectives of the church interiors of Saenredam and Neeffs gained Houckgeest immense popularity in The Netherlands, but it was to be another half-century before the two-point construction appeared in Italy in the hands of Canaletto."
https://www.webexhibits.org/sciartperspective/raphaelperspective6.html

>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

Looks like you're familiar with drawthrough method obviously, but yeah there is some inconsistencies in the perspective, but the drawings major issue is the hairy lines, also once you have that down don't get lost in the details, make sure it still reads as the object intended from a distance. You could also try drawing some mechanical objects in a 3 point perspective and see how you do. Hope that helps although You've probably heard similar advice before

Managed to quit reddit entirely but the addiction to scrolling still shows up in one way or other way. But it seems to be getting much better recently for some unexplicable reason , returning back to my original , restless self (still pretty lacking in energy but there seems to be progress). Maybe its better sleep or not trying to turn everything into "productivity' and turning everything into a grind like main stream self improvement tells you to do. Counter intuitively, like a chinese finger trap, I seem to have more fun and be MORE productive when I do not try to be productive.

The only thing I could pin-point the improvement to is:
-Stopped watching as much self improvement content
-Had a pretty big period of self-indulgence when it comes to scrolling and it felt like shit, but without the "muh productivity" backround guilt that is basically backround chatter. Causing my brain to seek out more "active" hobbies subconciously, almost as if my muse is starting to come back from the dead.
-Stopped using stress/fear as a producitivty tool (mostly because it stopped working as such)

posts.com: How'd you go about rendering something like this with just a pencil?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Experience with pencils of different grades, applying smooth consistent values with your pencils, knowing where to pull with a kneaded eraser, an understanding of perspective and forms, a firm grasp of value structures, experience and time. Essentially... rigorous application of the fundamentals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Japanese study the same fundamentals as us, ano.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485753
do different grade pencils really make a difference? I thought I could conquer the world with just a HB2 pencil

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485761
Makes a huge difference. Pencils aren't expensive anyway. You can get the essentials and it shouldn't cost you more than $15 in total.

As the other anon said though: it takes a firm understanding of pretty much everything. Lots of practice. Start with just shading drapery, or general anatomy, then work your way up. Otherwise you'll likely overwhelm yourself by starting something extensive and ruining it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485761
get a B2(it covers most of the range you'll need w/o abusing the paper too much) mechanical pencil(you'll never want to go back to HB), and try different kinds of paper too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485761
The range of pencils you use determines your value range. You won't have as wide a range if you use only HB. That's fine; many beautiful drawings have been made with a lighter value range. But if you want to go from black to white, you'll have a much easier time using 3 or 4 different leads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You don't. You probably won't ever overcome it. But that's okay. A lot of successful artists who are really good at their craft still doubt themselves in their work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Start small.

Don't expect whatever you put onto your canvas or page to be perfect or even good. As someone who is learning, be easy on yourself, and experiment. Even go aa far as trying different media. I got bored with the tedium of drawing in pencil, scanning the bits,cleaning them up in Photoshop, and assembling them into panels to do my comics,and discovered Second Life,a place built entirely by its user base,and it hypnotized me for half a decade. What simple Photoshopping skills I had served me well, and I made fantastic things doing simple texture manipulation. Mandelbulb flowers, crystal grass,animated paintings and lava hot tubs. These skills that you struggle with in traditional art mediums may flourish in others,especially the new 21st century kinds.

This thread gave me all I needed to know about this board. It's full of people with no talent or abstractist thinking who spend years and years trying to fit into being an artist, Or Illustrator or anything. They spend a lot of money and time on the BEST NEW equipment thinking it will make them better and it does produce a better product but at the end of the day, there are two realms when it comes to professions like these (To put it simply, Call them abstract and then traditional) and one needs to respect the other whichever they reside in
It's much like /mu/ when you post music.
Your art is awesome OP, whoever this is. The use of white is incredibily impressive . I'm always interested in art that needs to be closely looked at and when I draw, sometimes I try to draw something that is a bit "tricky" to discern what it truly is, Opening the work to multiple interpretations other than the artists.

>>6476156
I've been a professional illustrator for 20 years now.
I used Photoshop for around 10 years for my work. Besides that I only tried other software for fun (Painter, PaintToolSAI, etc.).
When I started to work on some comics related projects I decided to try CSP (Still called Manga Studio at the time), because a few art friends said it had nice tools for drawing line-art.
It was love at first sight, because of it's pencils/inks brush engine and the feel of the brushes. CSP has the ability to use your stroke speed as a line thickness modifier and it allowes me to rotate my canvas (photoshop introduced that feature later on but it's crap to this day), which at the time was a game changer for me (check pic attached). Photoshop simply couldn't compete anymore for natural/traditional looking line-art.
At first I still used Photoshop for coloring and painting my line drawings, but then I completely moved away from it and fully switched to CSP.

CSP pros (vs Photoshop):
- much better line art brushes and engine
- canvas rotation (photoshop with his inertia thing is total crap)
- better color mixing brushes
- better perspective and ruler tools (out of the box at least)
- more stable (I haven't used Photoshop seriously in almost a decade, so this might have changed)
- cheaper

CSP cons (vs Photoshop):
- doesn't support modern multi core processors (when I switched to CSP back in the day, this wasn't an issue, since Photoshop was a resources consuming always crashing mess)
- more limited for custom brushes that involve painting

>>6476156
Long text well about my experiences with PS vs CSP
If you're new to digital art, I would still learn this first as this will force you to learn the brush system and all the basics. If you know Photoshop, you know everything. You can literally get hired at lots of places for just being able to show you can use Photoshop well.
People say that CSP runs faster but I don't think this is true. Unoptimized CSP runs faster, but if you just google "Photoshop 60 fps" "Making Photoshop Faster" from Borodante or KNKL you'll find that Photoshop can fully utilize multithreaded machine setups. Even with higher end PC builds, I've noticed Photoshop runs faster than CSP, even after tweaking settings for both. For some reason the cursor on Photoshop just tracks directly behind your pen much more accurately than CSP by a tiny margin, whereas CSP you have to do extensive fuckery to get that to be the close to the same.
For CSP The Pen pressure is more customizable meaning I have more options for line brushes and adjusting things. This is not as big of an advantage as you'd think though as for PS the Pen pressure control out of the box works great already, whereas in CSP you usually have to fuck around for a bit to get it feel right. Usually I end up changing all my pens to a straight or slight curve and make everything dependent on my tablet curve pressure anyway.
I still use CSP mainly for 2 reasons:
The program is constantly getting better and better, whereas the newer versions of Photoshop is actually getting worse than CS6 for painting artwork. With the future updates, it will surpass PS
CSP EX has a built in storyboarding feature that is extremely valuable for organizing and making a workflow for making manga/comics and an industry level animation timeline workflow. I've only ever dabbled in those, but I like the feeling that if I ever wanted to make personal projects CSP already has me covered.

I went to a drawing school for 1 year, but honestly I would go to a place like that to meet people more than to efficiently learn how to draw/paint.
It's a nice experience but it's not worth the money for something you can do just by yourself, especially when the internet exists.
Equipment wise, to just learn to draw, you really need the bare minimum, just cheap copy paper and a pencil, for the courses just use youtube and the infinite amount of masters work that the internet puts at your disposal.
Even if you don't have a pc or a phone of any kind, just buy some books of comic books.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6486576
The material cost is part of it (which will differ widely depending on your medium i.e there's no need to buy paints or much else apart from a tablet if you're drawing digitally) but you also have to consider the time cost. Time is money as they say and the hours you spend practicing drawing could be spent at a minimum wage job. Until you can make $12 an hour or whatever off your art financially speaking you're better off cleaning toilets.
Internet connection (or a library card) a notebook and a pencil that's literally all you need to start practicing. Find art you like online or in books and try to copy it (not trace) by having it as a reference. Only look at the reference when you get stuck, try to draw what you saw from memory as much as you can. Watch free youtube videos from artists there's a lot of them

In the case of cultivating a skill like painting / drawing you agree it takes much more time than it does money, so pointing out that time is actually money too is helpful.
I also answered his question directly in the second part of my post.

By the way you're interpreting all of this as if (you) asked the question, but you didn't. OP did. And OP wants to know how much this will cost which means money is a consideration for him. He's living in reality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484770
Drawing daily helps you to improve and building this habit helps to get hours in. Once you've created the habit, taking a day or two off isn't the biggest deal in the world. For things like art, a super strict schedule isn't ideal for most people. You'll need experiment to find what works for you. People here act like you will lose all of your progress. Just be careful not to let the break extend for too long. Taking a deliberate break of a specified amount of time and getting back into is much better than ignoring your urges to rest and then burning out completely and ending up taking weeks or months off. Most of the time after a short break I actually come back with a noticeably improved.
Also, instead of taking a complete break you can try a different medium, method, subject matter, environment etc. It helps to change things up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

Idk, I guess it depends on why you want to take a break, and what your goals in art is. 30min minimum per day isn't a lot of time to spend drawing imo and I can't really see how you would get burnt out from at least keeping that up. I've spent between 5-12 hours drawing each day these past two months and the times I felt like I wanted to quit I just asked myself if my goal within the next years is to improve my art or play videogames and watch garbage videos, then I look at some dope artwork and drawing for a couple more hours is easy. I've cut away a lot of distractions though which helps a lot, got rid of my internet, never had a tv, so I only have internet at work and I pay my bills here at work and post on 4chan like right now.

I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

How did you guys break through the limit? Is the solution really just to keep drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

I'm stuck at 230 or so but I only do original stuff mostly. Try doing fanart or drawing bigger account OCs. The only reason I am at 230 and not 30 is because I did art for someone's OC I like and they RT'd it. But do it only if you like their art otherwise it's scummy imo.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6451767
I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The more you understand something, the less likely you are to fuck it up. If you have a feel for the sizes of certain bones and mobility of joints, you'll be less likely to mess up limb proportions or have body parts bent in ways that they cannot. Even during observation knowing the skeleton (and muscles) will help you. Learning the skeleton is part of understanding the "why" of the human figure, and like with most things, shit is easier to understand, remember, and reproduce if you can grasp the underlying fundamentals and not merely memorizing results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485326
Copying a skeleton in detail isn't helpful. But it is helpful to learn a simplified skeleton, like the one taught in "Basic Human Anatomy" by Roberto Osti, that gives the overall forms, proportions and alignments, because 1) parts of the skeleton show just below the surface; and 2) you will need a basic skeleton you can draw quickly to facilitate learning the muscles.
Also, the skeleton is very important in understanding and drawing the joints, especially knees and elbows.

posts.sub: Schizo take on social media feedback
posts.com:
So I just post stuff I've occasionally drawn on insta for the sake of it - who knows maybe it hits the right spot for someone else. I also follow a few people whose style and art I really like and sometimes express it through an appreciative comment, a share and sometimes join their art contests. Couple of them are big-ish i.e. 10k+ follows or something and they seemed to welcome this feedback to the point where they follow me back, "like" my work and sometimes we have a chat about the community and art or whatever. All cool. Nice.

The issue begins when I start getting praise comments/feedback from them. Of course feedback is nice, sure. Everyone likes getting that nice uplifting comment. But I really value genuine feedback.

Recently I've come to think the positive feedback/messages I get from those artists are just forced back scratching with no value. I may have no following and thus they probably try to support, but this support sounds fake to the point where it feels condescending.

Like, you don't give a shit about my art, why pretend? I don't draw things you care about. I'm no striving artist. I'm just an average joe pinup animeshit artist to pass my time.

I guess you want to get it off your chest that you've "now supported me back" since I went up your ass, but now it has an opposite effect. I don't believe anything they say anymore. It instead hurts because in the beginning I thought shit was genuine and I had actual artists liking my work. I gave up and disabled comments/shares. I'd rather get nothing over bs.

So did I hit a shit community corner where children are indoctrinated to hugbox or is this the norm I'm too stupid to understand?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474228
I’ve gone through several phases of ‘fun pen’

many years ago I liked the 005 micron because it was so fine, and felt sexy to use. But it is completely impractical to sketch with because the nib wears down so fast.

Then i upgraded my paper from cheap copy paper to heavy smooth card stock. I was super into the 01 micron, until I discovered the plastic nib PN micron. The PN is super robust, and you can get some line weights with it. It draws fast and is my favorite sketching pen.

I used the PN until a buddy got me into using a 2mm lead holder with HB lead. Now for quick sketches I use the lead holder and went back to cheap copy paper. The toothy paper feels really good with the pencil.

Recently, I went back to the 005 on the smooth copy paper for some studies (pic rel). The 005 felt just as good as I had remembered, but you really need to be purposeful and you can’t just dick around and make scribbles or the nib turns to a nub.

Here is the list of pens I thought I would like, but find infuriating
>pocket brush pen
Fuck this thing. It’s too slow, the line weight is nice, but the ink is so thin and weak, I’d rather use a dip pen. I also hate the wavy hand tremors that show up when i draw with it. Definitely not for sketching

>dip pen
The worst pen. The learning curve is just way too high. I spent 2 yrs trying to ink with it. It’s even slower than the brush pen because you have to clean the tip and dip every 2 minutes. Then wait for the ink to dry so you don’t smear it. Probably the most unfun pen I’ve ever used. I never have a good time inking with it. The ink is either too thick or too thin or the nib is worn, the ink splatters, and my desk is covered in soggy ink soaked tissues like I just jerked off a swarm of squid.

Pens:

Pretty great brush pens, although SC and SB are the most fun for me.
>Kuretake Bimoji brush pens
also big favorites of mine although I use the biggest brushes the most.

If you're into sumi-e or want a lot of variety in line width while inking then I recommend giving them a try. I especially like to sketch in these when I'm feeling a little mischievous.

Pencils:
>Pentel 0.5 mm (205)
Pretty cheap and fun to make more precise linework in. Feels really sharp. Use this the most for practicing more technical work/studies.
>Mitsubishi 2B pencil
I love to sketch in this the most, especially for thumbnails or more gestural work. It's smooth like butter and feels great to draw in. Though they get pretty small fairly quickly due to how soft the lead is so I definitely recommend getting a pencil extender if you buy a pack (I just use General's)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472850
Da Vinci's treatise on painting?
https://www.gutenberg.org/files/46915/46915-h/46915-h.htm

Painting back then was in its infancy; its teaching is much more "recipe-based" and less systematic than it is today ("if you want to paint that kind of stuff, then do this and that"; Cennini is a great example of it).

For instance, back then, color wasn't understood as hue/value/saturation. Such systems aren't perfect, but they are incredibly useful to handle colors. My point is, even if you aim at studying ancient techniques, don't neglect modern refinements.

>>6483035
What this anon posted >>6483087 was what I was talking about. Here's what was always copypasted to back up the image:

"Fundamentals before anime" is a kind of sequential thinking that creates artists who simply can't draw anime. You can use anime to study your fundamentals. They aren't mutually exclusive. You can also study realism and anime simultaneously.

Pic related is from the foreword of that popular アニメ私塾 book by a guy in the Japanese anime industry. See the triangle?
>上手い絵の模写: 上手い人の絵の記号(絵のパターン)を手に入れる
>Copying good drawings: acquiring the symbols of skilled people's drawings (the patterns of the drawings)
>実物の線画化:実物を理解することで、上手い人の絵が理解できる
>Real life drawing: by understanding real life, we can understand skilled people's drawings
>創作活動全般: 落書きや作品制作
>General original creation: sketching, complete OC works etc

Quote from the foreword:
>こうして、学生時代は「自主制作アニメを作る」「上手い絵の模写」「実物の線画化」のトライアングルを繰り返すことで劇的に上達していき、絵を描き始めてからわずか3年でスタジオジブリの入社試験に合格することができました。
>In this way, I made extreme progress during my school years by repeating a triangle of doing my own original anime drawings, copies of good drawings, and life drawings, and only 3 years after picking up drawing I was able to pass Studio Ghibli's employment test.

He was 19 when he started drawing.

Pic related also shows drawings from before he started practising deliberate copying as well as his original anime drawings from ~2 years after that.


Thus ends the copypasta. All this is to say, it's not the "Krenz" method, and if you see someone referring it as such you would do well to gently correct them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483087
Ok, so I'm not the only one great. Yeah, I used to have links saved on my iPod when artists (and writers) were very transparent in how directly they used their inspirations. Still sometimes go out to find the clips where Rapoza and Kopinski talked and encouraged copying. 'It will still be you at the end of the day.'. I just always had a paranoia that the things I copied, once recalled from imagination would get the internet art drama fiends right at my gate calling me a 'plagiarist', also along side worrying that my art 'wasn't good enough to post'. I remember really wanting to post to CA.org back in my early teens, but while Miles Johnson was getting mad Concept Art gains, I was dealing with this anxiety. The good thing about the internet, Youtube especially is getting to see artists workflow were they use references and where they talked about copying as a youth. Would have been nice to know earlier, but now I'm just making up for lost time.
